page.title: 16Newton-on-Ouse Feast.
page.content: In the nineteenth century Newton Feast was a two-day holiday held at Whitsuntide.All the villagers were involved and the"River King"sailed up the River Ouse bringing more people. Events included a pipe-smoking competition,Punch and Judy show,swing boats and coconut shies. The annual feast died out in the 1930s but started again in 1980.At the modern feast,held in June,there is a raft race on the river,fancy dress and fishing competitions,an ox-roast on the village green and other popular attractions.Stalls,with goods to sell and games of skill and chance,line the village street.In the evening a barn dance is held at White House Farm. Money raised at the feast goes to village charities and organisations.
